Yes, it is recommended that children brush their teeth at least twice a day - in the morning and before bed. Brushing twice a day helps to remove plaque, prevent cavities and gum disease, and keep teeth and gums healthy.

Apart from brushing twice a day, children may also need to brush after meals and snacks, especially if they have eaten sugary or starchy foods, which can stick to teeth and build up bacteria that cause decay. For optimal oral health, children can rinse their mouth with water or chew sugarless gum after meals as well. 

It is important to supervise young children and ensure they are brushing correctly and thoroughly. Children should use a pea-sized amount of toothpaste that contains fluoride and brush in circular motions for at least two minutes, covering all the surfaces of their teeth and gums. Parents should also assist or supervise children brushing their teeth until they are about eight years old to ensure that they are brushing properly.

Regular dental visits are also important to maintain good dental hygiene habits and address any potential oral health issues.
